School of Resource and Environmental Engineering Hefei University of Technology Hefei 230009 PR China Natural siderite modified TiO2 (Sid/TiO2) catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation method, and the Sid/TiO2 prepared under optimized conditions was loaded on ceramic filter tube (ST-CFT) through impregnating method. The results showed Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst had the best denitrification effect when the mass ratio of siderite was 0.3 and the calcination temperature was 450 °C. The NOx conversion efficiency reached more than 95 % at reaction temperature was 275–350 °C when NO initial concentration of 500 ppm, and gas hourly space velocity (GHCV) for 36,000 h−1. While the catalyst's median particle size (d50) was 5.3 μm, the slurry concentration was 7.5 wt%, and the face velocity (FV) was 1.5 m/min, NOx conversion efficiency of the ST (4)-CFT (7.5) reached 100 % at reaction temperatures ranging from 275 to 375 °C. It also revealed excellent water, sulfur, and alkali resistance. Compared with pure siderite catalyst, the crystallinity of active component α-Fe2O3 was decreased by introducing Ti carrier, and the utilization efficiency and dispersibility of the active center were improved. The synergistic effect of Fe and Ti improved the acid center density and Brønsted acid content of the catalyst, which promoted low-temperature SCR performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitric oxide Siderite-derived catalyst TiO2 Catalyst filter tube NH3-SCR Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Glass, cement, and other non-electric kiln flue gas temperature fluctuation ranges were large (150–400 °C), with high content of dust (rich in alkali metals), nitrogen oxides (NOx), and sulfur dioxide (SO2). Caused serious environmental problems such as acid rain, photochemical haze, and threatens human health [1–3]. Traditionally, series dust collectors, desulfurization equipment, and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) units were used to purify flue gas. It increased the floor area and operation energy consumption of the system, and more equipment reduced the stability of the system operation [4,5]. The catalytic filter (CF) combined dust removal and SCR, which had obvious advantages in the collaborative removal of various pollutants, gradually became a hot spot of integrated removal technology [6]. Miao et al. [7] and Kim et al. [8] achieved NOx conversion efficiency exceeding 90 % at 250∼350 °C, using V-W/Ti filters prepared by microwave drying and ball milling spin coating methods, respectively. Pan et al. [9] used TiO2 aerogel-modified MnOX/SiC ceramic membrane to achieve over 80 % NOx conversion efficiency within 120–180 °C. Shan et al. [10] performed in-situ deposition of Fe-WOx heterogeneous catalysts on SSFF (stainless steel fiber filter), demonstrated >85 % NOx conversion rate, excellent selectivity, and tolerance towards H2O and SO2 at temperatures of 275–350 °C. Practice had been proven that the combination of dry flue gas desulfurization and CF could effectively remove SO2, NOx, and hydrogen chloride in flue gas, and more than 99 % of dust [11]. The fibrous support layer and dense membrane layer effectively protected the catalyst inside the CF from poisoning by SO2 and alkali metals, and the developed pore structure provided sufficient attachment points for catalyst loading [9]. Existing CFs mainly utilized commercial V-W/Ti catalysts [12,13]. The limitations of V/Ti catalysts such as high and narrow temperature windows [12] became increasingly prominent, and its susceptibility to poisoning by alkali metals/H2O/SO2 [13], and biotoxicity [14]. Therefore, the research on Mn, Ce, Fe, Ni, Cu, and other vanadium-free catalysts gradually became a hot topic [9]. In recent years, FeOx catalysts had been extensively studied from micro-morphology [15], crystal structure [16,17], and preparation method [18]. It was proved that the FeOx catalyst was environmentally friendly, low-cost, and had excellent medium to high temperatures SCR activity, and N2 selectivity [19,20]. Siderite was widely distributed in China, and its main components were FeCO3 and SiO2 [21,22]. Due to the decomposition of FeCO3 after heat treatment of siderite, mesoporous materials with α-Fe2O3 as the main crystalline phase will be formed. With strong adsorption capacity and certain SCR activity, it had been proven to have the potential to treat waste gas [21]. Therefore, siderite was an ideal precursor material for FeOx catalysts. Currently, research on SCR catalysts based on siderite mainly focused on performance enhancement through heat treatment [22] or impregnation of Mn, Ce, Zr, W, and other metallic elements [23,24] to enhance SCR properties. However, it still had some defects such as poor reduction, low-temperature activity, and coexistence poisoning of H2O and SO2, which required further modification research [25,26]. Transition/rare earth elements (Ce [27], Mn [28], Cu [29], and W [30]) and other elements were often used as active components or additives of SCR catalysts. Among them, Ti was widely used as a carrier for SCR catalysts to improve the active ingredients' dispersion, surface acidity, and sulfur resistance [31,32]. In addition, the synergistic effect between Ti-Fe could promote the improvement of NH3-SCR performance [9,33]. In present study, the optimum preparation conditions of TiO2 supported nature siderite and Sid/TiO2 loaded on blank ceramic filter tube (CFT) through impregnating method were systematically discussed. The effects of filtration velocity (FV), H2O, SO2, and alkali metals (Na, K, and Ca) on the NH3-SCR performance of ST-CFT (Sid/TiO2-CFT) were discussed. The physicochemical properties of Sid/TiO2 and ST-CFT were analyzed using XRF, XRD, SEM&TEM, XPS, BET, and H2-TPR&NH3-TPD techniques. The study was expected to give a reference for research a new catalytic filter tube with simultaneous dust removal and denitrification. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials and preprocessing Ti(SO4)2, NH3·H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, Na2SiO3, NH4Cl, NaCl, KCl, and CaCl2 used in the experiment were all analytical reagents. Natural siderite was obtained from Daxigou of Shanxi, China, which was mechanically crushed and sieved (200 mesh) for reserve use. The CFT was produced by Jiangsu Saitu New Material Technology Co., Ltd. To facilitate the test, the CFT was cut into L (20 mm) × D (16 mm) cylinders, washed with alcohol, dried at 105 °C, and weighed for use. The XRF chemical composition analysis of Siderite and CFT were shown in Table 1 . The Siderite used in the experiment had low iron content and contained mainly Fe, Si, O, Al, K, and a small amount of Mg and Mn elements. The CFT was mainly composed of Al, Si, and O elements. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1911 g of Ti(SO4)2 was dissolved in deionized water, and a certain quality of siderite powder were added and mixed thoroughly. Then added NH3·H2O and stirred vigorously until the pH >9. Continued the reaction for 0.5 h and let the precipitate aged for 2 h. After filtration, the precipitates were dried at 105 °C and calcined at different temperatures for 4 h. After cooling, the catalyst was pressed into 40∼60 mesh, and named Sid (X)/TiO2 (Y), the X and Y respectively represented the mass proportion of siderite in the catalyst, and the calcination temperature (°C). 2.2.2 Preparation of ST-CFT The optimum catalyst with different particle sizes was prepared by wet ball milling. Then configured into different solid contents of the catalyst slurry, and mixed for 0.5 h. The pre-treated CFT was placed into the slurry for ultrasonic impregnation for 10 mins and finally weighed after drying at 105 °C. Each catalytic filter was loaded through the impregnating method twice. Finally, calcined at the set temperature for 4 h, cooled for use, named ST (M)-CFT (N), where M and N respectively represented the milling time (h) and the slurry concentration (wt%). 2.2.3 Preparation of alkaline poisoning catalytic filter tube and powder catalyst The alkali-poisoned ST-CFT was prepared by the impregnation method, and a certain mass of NaCl, KCl, and CaCl2 (2 wt% of the catalyst, measured by alkali metal) was dissolved in deionized water. The alkali solution was uniformly dripped onto the optimal ST-CFT surface and then dried in the oven. Finally, it calcined at the set temperature for 4 h, cooled, and reserved, recorded as 2Na-CFT, 2K-CFT, and 2Ca-CFT, respectively. The alkali-poisoning powder catalysts were prepared by the same method and were denoted as 2Na-ST, 2K-ST, and 2Ca-ST respectively. 2.3 Catalyst activity testing The calculation method for the loading rate of the catalyst was as follows: (1) ω = W 1 − W 0 W 0 × 100 % Where, W0 was the weight of CFT (g) and W1 was the weight of ST-CFT (g). The activity of the Sid (X)/TiO2 (Y) and ST (M)-CFT (N) samples were tested in the fixed-bed reactor system (Fig. 1 ). The simulated gas composition consisted of 500 ppm NO and NH3, 3 vol.% O2, 100 ppm SO2 (during use), 10 vol.% H2O (during use), and was balanced with Ar gas. The total gas flow rate was 300 mL/min, and the reaction temperature ranged from 50 to 400 °C. The gas flow rates for each component were adjusted using mass flow controllers (Beijing Qixing D07) and mixed thoroughly in a mixing tank. Then it was introduced into quartz catalytic reaction tube containing the Sid (X)/TiO2 (Y) or ST (M)-CFT (N) sample for the reaction. Real-time monitoring of NO concentration was measured using a flue gas analyzer (MADUR, GA-12Plus, Austria). N2, NH3, and N2O concentrations at the outlet were analyzed using Thermo Trace 1300 GC. The NOx conversion efficiency and N2 selectivity were calculated respectively as the following formula: (2) N O x conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in ) × 100 % (3) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 × [ N 2 O ] out [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 Where, [NOx]=[NO]+[NO2], [NO]in and [NO]out represented the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO, respectively, ppm. [NO2]in and [NO2]out represented the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO2, respectively, ppm. [NH3]in and [NH3]out represented the inlet and outlet concentrations of NH3, respectively, ppm. [N2O]out represented the outlet concentrations of N2O, ppm. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition of Siderite and CFT was analyzed by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF, Shimadzu XRF-1800, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM Talos F200X G2, China) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi Regulus 8230, Japan) were used to analyze sample morphology and elemental distribution coupled with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). The laser diffraction particle size analyzer (LDPSA, Mastersizer 2000, UK) was used to determine the particle size distribution of the powder catalysts. The crystal structure of the catalysts was analyzed through powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Dandong DX-2700, China) using Cu-Kα radiation. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts were analyzed by a liquid nitrogen physisorption analyzer (BET, Quantach-Autosorb-IQ3, USA). Atomic valence states and binding energies of the samples were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific ESCALAB-250 Xi, USA) with Al-Kα radiation, with the standard binding energy of C1s set at 284.8 eV. The reducibility of the catalysts was analyzed using a hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction analyzer (H2-TPR, VDSorb91 x). The surface acidity of the catalysts was determined using a temperature-programmed desorption analyzer (NH3-TPD, Auto Chem II-2920). Pyridine Fourier quantitatively determined the acidity and acid content of the catalyst transform infrared spectrometer (Py-FTIR, Bruker tensor 27, Vertex 80 V). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimal preparation conditions of Sid (X)/TiO2 (Y) and N2 selectivity Fig. 2 (a) showed the NOx conversion efficiency of the catalysts with different components. It was observed that the max NOx conversion efficiency of pure siderite (450) and pure TiO2 (450) catalysts were only 77.6 % and 14.0 % over the 50–400 °C. Introducing TiO2 could significantly improve the NOx conversion efficiency of the catalyst, when the mass proportion of siderite was 0.3, the catalytic efficiency reached the optimum condition. The NOx conversion efficiency of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst reached more than 95% in the range of 275∼350 °C. In addition, the Fe2O3 (0.3)/TiO2 (450) control group was synthesized by precipitation method. It was found that the two catalysts have similar denitrification performance at high temperatures above 275 °C. In the low temperatures, Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) was superior to the effect of Fe2O3 (0.3)/TiO2 (450). The results indicated that siderite had good potential and application prospects as Fe source to prepare industrial denitrification catalysts. Fig. 2(b) showed the effect of NOx conversion efficiency on different calcination temperatures of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (Y) catalysts. When the calcination temperature was 350 °C and 550 °C, the denitrification efficiency decreased. The reason was that when calcined at 350 °C, FeCO3 could not be completely transformed into active components to participate in the reaction [34,35]. Calcination at 550 °C increased the active component's crystallinity, decreasing the specific surface area and SCR activity [23,36]. In addition, the NOx conversion efficiency of Sid (0.3)/SiO2 (450) catalyst with SiO2 as the carrier was lower than that of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) in almost the whole test range. This indicated that there could be synergistic effect between Fe-Ti. Therefore, we determined the Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst was the optimal powder catalyst. Fig. 2(c) depicted the N2 selectivity outcomes of three catalysts. From 50 to 400 °C, Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) demonstrated significantly higher N2 selectivity than Siderite (450), and at 400 °C, it could remain above 90 %. The results indicated that introducing TiO2 enhanced the catalyst's NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity. 3.2 Optimal preparation conditions of ST (M)-CFT (N) The preparation conditions of each ST (M)-CFT and the effect of milling time on the median particle size of the catalyst were shown in Table 2 . It could be observed that the particle size of the catalyst decreased with the increase of milling time. Fig. 2(d) showed the NOx conversion efficiency of CFT and ST (M)-CFT (M = 2, 4, 6) (loading rates were all around 20 wt%). The NOx conversion efficiency of CFT was only 20–30 %. With the decrease in catalyst particle size, the NOx conversion efficiency of the ST (M)-CFT increased gradually. Among them, the NOx conversion efficiency of ST (4)-CFT reached 100 % in the range of 275–375 °C. This indicated that wet ball milling effectively reduced the particle size of the catalyst, promoted the dispersion of catalyst particles in the CFT, and was conducted to the improvement of SCR activity [37]. However, the NOx conversion efficiency of ST (6)-CFT with the smallest particle size was slightly improved. The result showed that when the particle size of the catalyst was lower than 5.3 μm, the decrease in particle size had no obvious effect on the denitrification performance of the ST-CFT. To explore the effect of catalyst load rate on the performance of the ST (4)-CFT (N), the concentration of catalyst slurry was changed, and the results were shown in Table 2 and Fig. 2(e). The findings indicated that as the slurry concentration increased, both the load rate and NOx conversion efficiency of the ST (4)-CFT (N) demonstrated a corresponding increase. It was also observed that ST (4)-CFT (7.5) at a load rate of 21.6 wt% exhibited a similar NOx conversion efficiency to ST (4)-CFT (10) at a load rate of 30.2 wt%. It showed that a higher catalyst loading rate could not effectively improve the denitrification performance of the ST-CFT. Fig. 2(f) described the influence of catalyst particle size and load rate on the pressure drop of the ST (M)-CFT (N). The results showed that the pressure drop of ST (M)-CFT (N) increased with the catalyst's particle size and loading rate. At 400 °C, the pressure drop of CFT was 0.75 kPa, and ST (4)-CFT (7.5) and ST (4)-CFT (10) with basically the same denitrification performance was 1.76 kPa and 1.87 kPa, respectively. Uphold economic efficient environmental protection concepts, and compared with the existing siderite catalysts and CFTs (Table 3 ), ST (4)-CFT (7.5) was chosen for further investigation. 3.3 Characterization 3.3.1 XRD Fig. 3 (a) showed the XRD patterns of Raw Siderite, Siderite (450), TiO2 (450), and Fe2O3 (0.3)/TiO2 (450). The main components of Raw Siderite were FeCO3 and SiO2 [35]. After calcination, the FeCO3 phase was transformed into the highly active component α-Fe2O3 (2θ=35.6°, 54.1° and 64.1°) [16]. The diffraction peaks of TiO2 (450) prepared by precipitation were all anatase-TiO2 diffraction peaks (2θ=25.3°, 38.0°, 48.0°, 55.0°) [8]. The control group Fe2O3 (0.3)/TiO2 (450) showed obvious anatases-TiO2 and α-Fe2O3 diffraction peaks. In Fig. 3(b), all Sid (X)/TiO2 (Y) samples showed obvious anatase-TiO2 diffraction peaks and weak α-Fe2O3 diffraction peaks. It indicated that α-Fe2O3 was dispersed on the TiO2 surface with a lower crystallinity, which was conducted to electron transfer and enhanced the catalyst's oxidation performance [38–40]. As the calcination temperature increased, the diffraction peak of FeCO3 gradually weakened and completely vanished at 450 °C. Meanwhile, the crystal phase of α-Fe2O3 remains unchanged and the diffraction peak gradually strengthened. Studies had shown that increasing temperature could promote the growth of α-Fe2O3 crystals [27], reducing the catalyst activity [35,41]. Fig. 3(c) showed that the main diffraction peaks of CFT were α-Al2O3, SiO2, and AlSiOx generated by the reaction of CFT during the production firing process [42]. The characteristic peaks of TiO2 and α-Fe2O3 could be observed in all ST (M)-CFT (N) samples, indicating the catalysts were successfully loaded onto the CFT. 3.3.2 SEM and TEM The morphologies of Raw Siderite, Siderite (450), and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) were observed by TEM. According to Fig. 4 (a), raw siderite had an irregular layered structure with a glassy appearance. Following calculations (Fig. 4(b)), the surface of Siderite became porous and developed nanoscale molten-grain-like structures. These structures created multiple nanochannels that increased the specific surface area of Siderite. As a result, gas diffusion and adsorption were facilitated, leading to an improved utilization rate of active components and SCR reaction rate [43,44]. The formation of micropores was related to FeCO3 decomposition and CO2 escape, as indicated by XRD results. In Fig. 4(c), the TEM image displayed spherical TiO2 nanoparticles prepared through precipitation. EDS element mapping analysis (Fig. 4(d∼ d-3)) showed that O, Ti, and Fe elements in Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) were highly coincident, indicating the active component α-Fe2O3 was highly dispersed on the TiO2 support. The CFT in Fig. 4(e) was composed of ceramic fibers stacked in an intertwined manner, exhibiting high porosity and pore size. The fiber diameter predominantly ranged between 1∼5 μm, with a rough surface that facilitated catalyst loading. EDS elemental analysis (Fig. 4(e-1∼e-3)) corroborated the composition of ceramic fibers primarily as O, Al, and Si elements, consistent with XRF and XRD results. Fig. 4(f) demonstrated the well-dispersed catalyst loading on the surface of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) fibers, without any visible agglomeration or pore blocking. EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 4(f-1∼f-5)) revealed a uniform distribution of TiO2 carrier and α-Fe2O3 active components on the fiber surface and pores, resulting in a high exposure rate of active sites and ensuring excellent catalytic activity. 3.3.3 BET The pore structure parameters, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of raw siderite, siderite (450), Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) and TiO2 (450) were shown in Table 4 and Fig. 5 . All samples exhibited type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and H4 hysteresis loops (Fig. 5(a)), indicated the presence of mesoporous properties [44,45]. Table 4 easily observed the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of Siderite (450) (68.3 m2/g, 8.8 nm, 0.07 cm3/g) were much larger than Raw Siderite (13.9 m2/g, 3.3 nm, 0.04 cm3/g). Combined with TEM analysis, it was easily concluded that this change was mainly due to the decomposition of siderite after calcination, causing many cracks. This resulted in a larger specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume, facilitating active site dispersion and gas reactant adsorption and activation [25,31]. With TiO2 doping, the specific surface area of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) (59.6 m2/g) decreased compared with Siderite (450) (68.3 m2/g) and TiO2 (450) (84.6 m2/g) (Table 4), which could be related to the coating of the porous structure by TiO2 [46]. However, it was worth noting that the denitrification performance of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) was better than Siderite (450) and TiO2 (450), indicating that the denitrification performance of the catalyst was not solely dependent on the specific surface area [25,47]. 3.3.4 XPS The elemental composition and valence distribution of the catalyst were analyzed using XPS, and the XPS spectra for each sample were shown in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6(a), Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 peaks were observed for Siderite (450) and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) at 711.0 eV and 724.5 eV. Two peaks were fitted respectively, attributed to Fe2+ and Fe3+ [18,34]. It was noteworthy that the Fe2p3/2 binding energy of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) was higher than that of Siderite (450). This indicated that the introduction of Ti changed the chemical environment of Fe species in Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) [28,36]. As can be seen from the atomic concentration calculation results in Table 5 , Fe3+/Fe in Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) (38.50 %) was higher than that in Siderite (450) (34.47 %). This showed an interaction between Fe-Ti, which could increase the Fe3+ content on the catalyst surface, and the surface acidity was improved, thus improving the denitrification effect of the catalyst [28,48]. In Fig. 6(b), the O1s spectra of all samples displayed two peaks, corresponding to surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα, 532 eV) and lattice oxygen (Oβ, 530 eV) [49]. It was commonly believed that Oα exhibited better migration and reactivity than Oβ, oxidized NO to NO2, and facilitated the rapid NH3-SCR reaction [50,51]. As shown in Table 5, it was found that Oα/O in Siderite (450) (78.81 %) was higher than that in Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) (43.94 %), but it showed a poor denitrification effect. This phenomenon could be because a high Oα content meant excessive oxidation ability, which caused rapid consumption of reducing agents and thus hindered the normal progress of the SCR reaction [49,52]. Fig. 6(c) showed that TiO2 (450) and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) had two peaks observed at 465 eV and 459 eV, corresponding to Ti4+2p1/2 and Ti4+2p3/2, respectively [53]. 3.3.5 H2-TPR The oxidation–reduction property of the catalyst played a key role in the NH3-SCR reaction. Fig. 7 (a) showed the H2-TPR characterization results of Siderite (450) and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450). Combined with XRD and XPS analysis, all the reduction peaks in the samples were FeOx reduction peaks. The reduction peaks of Siderite (450) at 297 °C and 489 °C correspond to the reduction process of α-Fe2O3→Fe3O4→FeO [54]. Compared with Siderite (450), Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) showed significantly different continuous overlapping reduction peaks in the range of 280–560 °C. The interaction between Fe3+ and Ti4+ species caused the Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst to exhibit different reducibility than Siderite (450) [55,56]. It was because part of the Fe species in Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) coated by TiO2, H2 diffusion was difficult, and oxidation capacity was reduced [55]. 3.3.6 NH3-TPD In the E-R or l-H mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, the adsorption of NH3 at the acidic site was an important step [57]. The surface acid properties of the sample were analyzed with NH3-TPD (Fig. 7). According to the position of the NH3 desorption peak, the corresponding acid sites were divided into weak acid (Brønsted (B) acid, below 150 °C), medium-strong acid (150–300 °C), and strong acid (Lewis (L) acid, above 300 °C) [58]. Notably, the number of Brønsted and medium-strong acid sites of Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) increased significantly compared to Siderite (450) (Fig. 7(c)). This showed that the doping of TiO2 enhanced the overall acidity of the catalyst, led to the generation of more B acids and medium-strong acids, facilitated the adsorption and activation of reactants, and enabled the SCR reaction to occur at lower temperatures [27,56,59]. 3.3.7 Py-FTIR The Py-FTIR spectra of Siderite (450), TiO2 (450), and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) were shown in Fig. 8 (a), (c) and (e). Bands near 1449 and 1611 cm−1 were adsorption of pyridine to L acid centers. 1540 and 1637 cm−1 were the adsorption bands of B acid centers, and 1489 cm−1 was the binding band of L acid and B acid centers [36,39,60]. Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) was easily observed to have similar Py-FTIR bands to Siderite (450) but with larger peak intensities and the presence of a new adsorption band of B acid center at 1637 cm−1. This change indicated that the introduction of TiO2 increased the total acid content of the catalyst and provided more B acid sites for the catalyst [28]. This was consistent with the acid content calculation results in Fig. 8(b), (d), (f) (TiO2 (450)>Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450)> Siderite (450)). Higher total acid content and B/L value (B acid center number: L acid center number) tend to facilitate NH3 adsorption and activation and NH3-SCR reaction of catalysts at low temperatures [25,39,47]. 3.3.8 Mechanism discussion Based on the above results and analysis. The TEM-EDS spectra (Fig. 4(d)) indicated that the elements of O, Fe, and Ti were uniformly distributed on the surface of the Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst. Its large specific surface area and small pore size (Table 4) facilitated the interaction between the active site and the reactive gas molecules. XPS analysis demonstrated that the introduction of Ti had an impact on the point charge balance in the catalyst, resulting in a high ratio of Fe3+ and Oα in the Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst (Table 5), which contributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies and the "fast SCR" reaction. Due to the addition of Ti, the chemisorption capacity of the acid site on the catalyst surface was significantly enhanced (primarily from the enhancement of B acid), and more NH3 was adsorbed and activated, promoting the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.4 Industrial applications and toxicity testing 3.4.1 Impact of FV Fig. 9 (a) depicted the effect of FV on the NOx conversion efficiency and system pressure drop of ST (4)-CFT (7.5). As the FV decreased (1.5→0.6 m/min), the residence time of flue gas in the system was prolonged, and the optimal activity temperature of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) was expanded from 275∼375 °C to 250∼375 °C. Therefore, ST (4)-CFT (7.5) showed excellent denitrification performance at all FVs. In addition, in terms of pressure drop, the system's pressure drop increased with the FV at the same temperature. When FV was 1.5 m/min, the pressure drop of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) at 400 °C was 1.76 kpa, and when FV was reduced to 0.6 m/min, the pressure drop was 1.07 kPa. 3.4.2 Alkaline resistance testing Research showed that alkali metal deposition on the catalyst surface, combined with surface acid sites, decreased adsorption capacity, and significantly reduced the catalyst's activity [61]. Fig. 9(b) illustrated the impact of Na, K, and Ca on the denitrification activity of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) (Fig. 9(b-1)) and Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) (Fig. 9(b-2)). The results showed that the three alkali metals inhibited the activity of the catalyst in varying degrees, with a toxicity order of K > Na > Ca, which was consistent with the findings of Fang et al. [62] and Du et al. [63]. Within the optimal temperature range of 200∼400 °C, the average NOx conversion efficiency decreased by 4.84 %, 8.32 %, and 14.52 % for 2Ca-CFT, 2Na-CFT, and 2K-CFT, respectively. Among them, 2K-CFT exhibited the highest deactivation level due to its stronger alkalinity, resulting in more severe catalyst poisoning and the greatest reduction in catalytic activity [64]. In addition, it was easy to notice that the deactivation degree of the powder catalysts was higher after alkali metals toxicity. The average NOx conversion decreases by 17.84 %, 32.32 %, and 42.92 %, respectively, at 200∼400 °C. This change was mainly attributed to the unique fibrous structure of the CFT (Fig. 4(e)), which could effectively filter fly ash containing alkali metals [61,64]. The direct contact between harmful substances and the internal catalyst was prevented, which weakened the toxic effect [65]. 3.4.3 Impact of H2O and SO2 on ST (4)-CFT (7.5) The tolerance of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) to H2O (g) (10 vol.%) and SO2 (100 ppm) was investigated at 275 °C (Fig. 10 (a)). When H2O (g) or SO2 was added alone, the NOx conversion efficiency decreased rapidly and stabilized at 93.2 % and 92.2 %, respectively. When H2O (g) (or SO2) was turned off, the NOx conversion efficiency quickly recovered to 100 % and 98.5 %. In addition, in the presence of both H2O (g) and SO2, ST (4)-CFT (7.5) could still show a NOx conversion efficiency of more than 85 %. When it stopped the water and sulfur poisoning, the NO conversion returned to 91.8 %. These results demonstrated the excellent water and sulfur tolerance of ST (4)-CFT (7.5). Considering the XRD spectra before and after the water resistance test (Fig. 10(b)), no significant changes were observed, indicating that high-temperature water vapor did not cause irreversible damage to the compositional structure of ST (4)-CFT (7.5). The decrease in conversion efficiency could be attributed to the competitive adsorption effect of H2O (g), which led to a reduction in NH3 participating in the SCR reaction, and decreased the catalyst activity [36]. XPS was used to analyze the surface atomic concentration of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) before and after the sulfur resistance test (Fig. 10(c)). After the sulfur resistance test, the atomic concentration of N and S on the surface of the filter tube increased by 0.57 % and 0.59 %, respectively. This indicated that the reaction of SO2 and NH3 generated amorphous ammonium sulfate and deposited it on the surface of the catalyst, causing partial pore diameter blockage of the catalyst and reducing the denitrification effect [44,66]. After closing SO2, the ammonium sulfate was decomposed gradually at 275 °C, and the denitrification efficiency gradually recovered. When water and sulfur coexisted, the competitive adsorption effect of H2O (g) promoted the formation of ammonium sulfate salts. This conclusion was verified by the further increase of the surface N (0.83 %) and S (0.77 %) element concentrations of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) (H2O+SO2) in Fig. 10(c), and the NOx conversion efficiency was further reduced. 3.4.4 Stability operation testing Based on the previous experimental tests, ST (4)-CFT (7.5) exhibited excellent catalytic activity and a wide temperature window. However, stability operation testing was conducted to assess its value for industrial applications. Fig. 11 depicted the stability of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) at NOx conversion rates of 100 % (T100: 275 °C), 80 % (T80: 215 °C), and 60 % (T60: 185 °C). Under T100, the NOx conversion rate of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) started to decline after 7 h of stable operation, and eventually stabilized at over 90 %, meeting the requirements for industrial applications. This indicated that ST (4)-CFT (7.5) had considerable industrial application value and stability. It was also noted that the stability of ST (4)-CFT (7.5) improved as the NOx conversion decreased. At T80, the NOx conversion rate began to decline slowly after 21 h of stable operation of ST (4)-CFT (7.5). In contrast, T60 demonstrated greater stability, with only a slight decrease throughout the test interval. 4 Conclusion (1) When the mass ratio of Siderite was 0.3, and the calcination temperature was 450 °C, the Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst represented more than 95 % NOx conversion efficiency and more than 90 % N2 selectivity at reaction temperature ranging from 275 to 350 °C. (2) Under the conditions of a catalyst particle size (d50) of 5.3 μm, loading rate of 21.6 wt%, and FV of 1.5 m/min, ST(4)-CFT(7.5) achieved 100 % NOx conversion efficiency at reaction temperature ranging from 275 to 375 °C. Furthermore, it exhibited exceptional resistance to water, sulfur, and alkali as well as stability. (3) TiO2 facilitated the dispersion of the active component α-Fe2O3, and enhanced the SCR activity of the catalyst. The synergistic effect between Fe and Ti species modified the reducibility of the catalyst, increased the total acid content, and improved the proportion of Brønsted acid, thereby benefiting low-temperature catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Natural siderite modified TiO2 (Sid/TiO2) catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation method, and the Sid/TiO2 prepared under optimized conditions was loaded on ceramic filter tube (ST-CFT) through impregnating method. The results showed Sid (0.3)/TiO2 (450) catalyst had the best denitrification effect when the mass ratio of siderite was 0.3 and the calcination temperature was 450 °C. The NOx conversion efficiency reached more than 95 % at reaction temperature was 275–350 °C when NO initial concentration of 500 ppm, and gas hourly space velocity (GHCV) for 36,000 h−1. While the catalyst's median particle size (d50) was 5.3 μm, the slurry concentration was 7.5 wt%, and the face velocity (FV) was 1.5 m/min, NOx conversion efficiency of the ST (4)-CFT (7.5) reached 100 % at reaction temperatures ranging from 275 to 375 °C. It also revealed excellent water, sulfur, and alkali resistance. Compared with pure siderite catalyst, the crystallinity of active component α-Fe2O3 was decreased by introducing Ti carrier, and the utilization efficiency and dispersibility of the active center were improved. The synergistic effect of Fe and Ti improved the acid center density and Brønsted acid content of the catalyst, which promoted low-temperature SCR performance.
